abstract.p: Jerome Priest letter recounts instance when Air France prohibited tourist-class passengers from disembarking until all first- and business-class passengers left cabin; Air France spokeswoman Diane Cornman defends practice (S)

The Travel section receives hundreds of letters from readers about their experiences with airline travel. Although most write to complain, a small number actually offer words of praise. Here is a selection from the last year:
To the Editor: If an airline cherishes one class of passengers at the expense of another, does it pay? Evidently Air France thinks so.

Upon landing in New York on a flight from Paris, the cabin crew blocked tourist-class aisles, prohibiting debarkation until we could see no more first- or business-class people. Finally, the ''steerage'' folks remonstrated loudly, shouting ''Enough!'' and ''Let us off!'' It was only then that we were allowed off.

Diane Cornman, an Air France spokeswoman, replies: Many major carriers allow first-class and business-class passengers to deplane first. There is a valid reason for this, in that the door for disembarking, in most circumstances, is the forward left door. They deplane first to allow for a smoother and more efficient disembarkation. It is also important to note that ''premium'' passengers on essentially every airline are offered special services, including allowing them to disembark quickly.
